Per the Colerain Police Department:

“The Police Department has been in contact with the Northwest Local School District and learned that the District is not mandating any online attendance during the ordered closing. Therefore, the Resolution passed by the Colerain Township Trustees in 2007 does not address school closures and the curfew is unenforceable. The Police Department will not be enforcing the daytime curfew because the Resolution, as written, does not give authority to do so.

Private businesses still have the right to impose curfews and restrict attendance on their property, this is not a Colerain Township matter.”

Northwest Local School District would like to recognize the following teachers who have been nominated for the C3 Outstanding Educator Award: Jayne Sayers (HELC), Victoria Case (PRE), Susan Houchen (WOMS), and Shawn Gilliand (NWHS).

The C3 award recognizes Greater Cincinnati teachers who demonstrate excellence in education through their strong knowledge of content and their use of innovative teaching methods that enable all students to learn. Recipients also must collaborate well with colleagues, serve in leadership roles, and be actively involved in the community.

Through the combined efforts of the University of Cincinnati, Northern Kentucky University, Xavier University, Mount St. Joseph University, and the Cincinnatus Association, award winners will be presented with a $500 cash prize and an award plaque noting their achievements. All winners, and those who have nominated them, will be honored at a banquet in February.

"Never underestimate the power of dreams and the influence of the human spirit. We are all the same in this notion: The potential for greatness lives within each of us." -Wilma Glodean Rudolph

Wilma Rudolph was an African-American sprinter born in Saint Bethlehem, Tennessee, who became a world-record-holding Olympic champion and international sports icon in track and field following her successes in the 1956 and 1960 Olympic Games.

Rudolph competed in the 200-meter dash and won a bronze medal in the 4 × 100-meter relay at the 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne, Australia. She also won three gold medals, in the 100- and 200-meter individual events and the 4 x 100-meter relay at the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome, Italy. Rudolph was acclaimed the fastest woman in the world in the 1960s and became the first American woman to win three gold medals in a single Olympic Games.

post_text: DID YOU KNOW? Children hear better than they read. According to Jim Trelease, author of Read-Aloud Handbook, a child's reading level isn't on par with his listening level until the eighth grade. Trelease says that parents "can and should be reading seventh-grade books to fifth-grade kids," as this helps gets kids buzzed about storylines and plots and will motivate them to keep reading. Reading aloud to them will keep kids coming back for more as they develop and improve their own independent reading skills! Reading about different topics will help broaden their horizons. https://www.huffpost.com/entry/why-we-should-continue-to_b_13775602?guccounter=1

post_text: Monfort Heights Elementary School students had a blast learning about literacy today! The Staff transformed the school into a Literacy Hospital and the students transformed into word surgeons, dissecting “guts” to find and build words! Our 4th grade students were challenged to write intake evaluations for Mr. Bear The Patient. They were then given the task to write a narrative to describe what happened to Mr. Bear. Cincinnati Children’s Hospital taught students how to discern between medicine and candy and the importance of asking parents if they are unsure! Big thanks to Cincinnati Children’s, Green Township Emergency Medical and Walgreens for your help! #RelentlessFocusOnLiteracy #NWLSDGobeyond

Music has a positive reaction on the brain. For children, music is essential to the development of literacy and motor skills and prepares students for school. Studies have even shown that music helps improve learning, reduces stress, improves memory recall and helps with auditory processing.

Our kids need music. Save our music program. #NWLSDgobeyond
